channel.title: Comments on: Tone woods and Solid Guitars. Debate settled, scientifically.
channel.description: Exegesis Hermeneutics Flux Capacitor of Truthiness

item.title: By: Roger Lewis
item.dc:creator: Roger Lewis
item.description: <br />DKGCustom8:10 PM1<br />Reply<br /> <br />+stampingdragon Please take your long winded debate, somewhere else.<br /><br />I will ban you from this channel if you continue to fill this thread up with STUFF. You're obviously a fighter for this cause, but I'm not here for you to repost long spiels born in other forums.<br /><br />From that blog: "to discern any qualitative sound difference the effect of the wood is not statistically significant in the signal"﻿<br />Show less<br /><br />stampingdragon8:15 PM<br /> <br />This paper alone settles this discussion for any scientifically minded person. http://www.lam.jussieu.fr/Membres/Pate/Fichiers/ArthurPate_SMAC2013_Poster.pdf<br />It makes very little difference it is true but it is empirically proven that a small difference exists which is of course both magnified and diminished in differing measures along the signal chain.<br />On statistical significance, how long is a piece of string?﻿
item.content:encoded:
DKGCustom8:10 PM1
Reply

+stampingdragon Please take your long winded debate, somewhere else.

I will ban you from this channel if you continue to fill this thread up with STUFF. You're obviously a fighter for this cause, but I'm not here for you to repost long spiels born in other forums.

From that blog: “to discern any qualitative sound difference the effect of the wood is not statistically significant in the signal”﻿
Show less

stampingdragon8:15 PM

This paper alone settles this discussion for any scientifically minded person. http://www.lam.jussieu.fr/Membres/Pate/Fichiers/ArthurPate_SMAC2013_Poster.pdf
It makes very little difference it is true but it is empirically proven that a small difference exists which is of course both magnified and diminished in differing measures along the signal chain.
On statistical significance, how long is a piece of string?﻿
